  3 | description: "Learn how to build your first client in MCP"
  4 | ---
  5 | 
  6 | In this tutorial, you'll learn how to build a client application that connects to MCP servers. It helps to have gone through the [Quickstart tutorial](/quickstart) that guides you through the basic of building your first server.
  7 | 
  8 | <Tabs>
  9 | <Tab title="Python">
 10 | 
 11 | ## System Requirements
 12 | 
 13 | Before starting, ensure your system meets these requirements:
 14 | - Mac or Windows computer
 15 | - Latest Python version installed
 16 | - Latest version of `uv` installed
 17 | 
 18 | ## Setting Up Your Environment
 19 | 
 20 | First, create a new Python project with `uv`: 
 21 | 
 22 | ```bash
 23 | # Create project directory
 24 | uv init mcp-client
 25 | cd mcp-client
 26 | 
 27 | # Create virtual environment
 28 | uv venv
 29 | 
 30 | # Activate virtual environment
 31 | # On Windows:
 32 | .venv\Scripts\activate
 33 | # On Unix or MacOS:
 34 | source .venv/bin/activate
 35 | 
 36 | # Install required packages
 37 | uv add mcp anthropic python-dotenv
 38 | 
 39 | # Remove boilerplate files
 40 | rm hello.py
 41 | 
 42 | # Create our main file
 43 | touch client.py
 44 | ```
 45 | 
 46 | ## Setting Up Your API Key
 47 | 
 48 | You'll need an Anthropic API key from the [Anthropic Console](https://console.anthropic.com/settings/keys).
 49 | 
 50 | Create a `.env` file to store it:
 51 | 
 52 | ```bash
 53 | # Create .env file
 54 | touch .env
 55 | ```
 56 | 
 57 | Add your key to the `.env` file:
 58 | ```bash
 59 | ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=<your key here>
 60 | ```
 61 | 
 62 | Add `.env` to your `.gitignore`:
 63 | ```bash
 64 | echo ".env" >> .gitignore
 65 | ```
 66 | 
 67 | <Warning>
 68 | Make sure you keep your `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` secure!
 69 | </Warning>
 70 | 
 71 | ## Creating the Client
 72 | 
 73 | ### Basic Client Structure
 74 | First, let's set up our imports and create the basic client class:
 75 | 
 76 | ```python
 77 | import asyncio
 78 | from typing import Optional
 79 | from contextlib import AsyncExitStack
 80 | 
 81 | from mcp import ClientSession, StdioServerParameters
 82 | from mcp.client.stdio import stdio_client
 83 | 
 84 | from anthropic import Anthropic
 85 | from dotenv import load_dotenv
 86 | 
 87 | load_dotenv()  # load environment variables from .env
 88 | 
 89 | class MCPClient:
 90 |     def __init__(self):
 91 |         # Initialize session and client objects
 92 |         self.session: Optional[ClientSession] = None
 93 |         self.exit_stack = AsyncExitStack()
 94 |         self.anthropic = Anthropic()
 95 |     # methods will go here
 96 | ```
 97 | 
 98 | ### Server Connection Management
 99 | 
100 | Next, we'll implement the method to connect to an MCP server:
101 | 
102 | ```python
103 | async def connect_to_server(self, server_script_path: str):
104 |     """Connect to an MCP server
105 |     
106 |     Args:
107 |         server_script_path: Path to the server script (.py or .js)
108 |     """
109 |     is_python = server_script_path.endswith('.py')
110 |     is_js = server_script_path.endswith('.js')
111 |     if not (is_python or is_js):
112 |         raise ValueError("Server script must be a .py or .js file")
113 |         
114 |     command = "python" if is_python else "node"
115 |     server_params = StdioServerParameters(
116 |         command=command,
117 |         args=[server_script_path],
118 |         env=None
119 |     )
120 |     
121 |     stdio_transport = await self.exit_stack.enter_async_context(stdio_client(server_params))
122 |     self.stdio, self.write = stdio_transport
123 |     self.session = await self.exit_stack.enter_async_context(ClientSession(self.stdio, self.write))
124 |     
125 |     await self.session.initialize()
126 |     
127 |     # List available tools
128 |     response = await self.session.list_tools()
129 |     tools = response.tools
130 |     print("\nConnected to server with tools:", [tool.name for tool in tools])
131 | ```
132 | 
133 | ### Query Processing Logic
134 | 
135 | Now let's add the core functionality for processing queries and handling tool calls:
136 | 
137 | ```python
138 | async def process_query(self, query: str) -> str:
139 |     """Process a query using Claude and available tools"""
140 |     messages = [
141 |         {
142 |             "role": "user",
143 |             "content": query
144 |         }
145 |     ]
146 | 
147 |     response = await self.session.list_tools()
148 |     available_tools = [{ 
149 |         "name": tool.name,
150 |         "description": tool.description,
151 |         "input_schema": tool.inputSchema
152 |     } for tool in response.tools]
153 | 
154 |     # Initial Claude API call
155 |     response = self.anthropic.messages.create(
156 |         model="claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022",
157 |         max_tokens=1000,
158 |         messages=messages,
159 |         tools=available_tools
160 |     )
161 | 
162 |     # Process response and handle tool calls
163 |     tool_results = []
164 |     final_text = []
165 | 
166 |     for content in response.content:
167 |         if content.type == 'text':
168 |             final_text.append(content.text)
169 |         elif content.type == 'tool_use':
170 |             tool_name = content.name
171 |             tool_args = content.input
172 |             
173 |             # Execute tool call
174 |             result = await self.session.call_tool(tool_name, tool_args)
175 |             tool_results.append({"call": tool_name, "result": result})
176 |             final_text.append(f"[Calling tool {tool_name} with args {tool_args}]")
177 | 
178 |             # Continue conversation with tool results
179 |             if hasattr(content, 'text') and content.text:
180 |                 messages.append({
181 |                   "role": "assistant",
182 |                   "content": content.text
183 |                 })
184 |             messages.append({
185 |                 "role": "user", 
186 |                 "content": result.content
187 |             })
188 | 
189 |             # Get next response from Claude
190 |             response = self.anthropic.messages.create(
191 |                 model="claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022",
192 |                 max_tokens=1000,
193 |                 messages=messages,
194 |             )
195 | 
196 |             final_text.append(response.content[0].text)
197 | 
198 |     return "\n".join(final_text)
199 | ```
200 | 
201 | ### Interactive Chat Interface
202 | Now we'll add the chat loop and cleanup functionality:
203 | 
204 | ```python
205 | async def chat_loop(self):
206 |     """Run an interactive chat loop"""
207 |     print("\nMCP Client Started!")
208 |     print("Type your queries or 'quit' to exit.")
209 |     
210 |     while True:
211 |         try:
212 |             query = input("\nQuery: ").strip()
213 |             
214 |             if query.lower() == 'quit':
215 |                 break
216 |                 
217 |             response = await self.process_query(query)
218 |             print("\n" + response)
219 |                 
220 |         except Exception as e:
221 |             print(f"\nError: {str(e)}")
222 | 
223 | async def cleanup(self):
224 |     """Clean up resources"""
225 |     await self.exit_stack.aclose()
226 | ```
227 | 
228 | ### Main Entry Point
229 | 
230 | Finally, we'll add the main execution logic:
231 | 
232 | ```python
233 | async def main():
234 |     if len(sys.argv) < 2:
235 |         print("Usage: python client.py <path_to_server_script>")
236 |         sys.exit(1)
237 |         
238 |     client = MCPClient()
239 |     try:
240 |         await client.connect_to_server(sys.argv[1])
241 |         await client.chat_loop()
242 |     finally:
243 |         await client.cleanup()
244 | 
245 | if __name__ == "__main__":
246 |     import sys
247 |     asyncio.run(main())
248 | ```
249 | 
250 | You can find the complete `client.py` file [here.](https://gist.github.com/zckly/f3f28ea731e096e53b39b47bf0a2d4b1)
251 | 
252 | ## Key Components Explained
253 | 
254 | ### 1. Client Initialization
255 | - The `MCPClient` class initializes with session management and API clients
256 | - Uses `AsyncExitStack` for proper resource management
257 | - Configures the Anthropic client for Claude interactions
258 | 
259 | ### 2. Server Connection
260 | - Supports both Python and Node.js servers
261 | - Validates server script type
262 | - Sets up proper communication channels
263 | - Initializes the session and lists available tools
264 | 
265 | ### 3. Query Processing
266 | - Maintains conversation context
267 | - Handles Claude's responses and tool calls
268 | - Manages the message flow between Claude and tools
269 | - Combines results into a coherent response
270 | 
271 | ### 4. Interactive Interface
272 | - Provides a simple command-line interface
273 | - Handles user input and displays responses
274 | - Includes basic error handling
275 | - Allows graceful exit
276 | 
277 | ### 5. Resource Management
278 | - Proper cleanup of resources
279 | - Error handling for connection issues
280 | - Graceful shutdown procedures
281 | 
282 | ## Common Customization Points
283 | 
284 | 1. **Tool Handling**
285 |    - Modify `process_query()` to handle specific tool types
286 |    - Add custom error handling for tool calls
287 |    - Implement tool-specific response formatting
288 | 
289 | 2. **Response Processing**
290 |    - Customize how tool results are formatted
291 |    - Add response filtering or transformation
292 |    - Implement custom logging
293 | 
294 | 3. **User Interface**
295 |    - Add a GUI or web interface
296 |    - Implement rich console output
297 |    - Add command history or auto-completion
298 | 
299 | ## Running the Client
300 | 
301 | To run your client with any MCP server:
302 | 
303 | ```bash
304 | uv run client.py path/to/server.py # python server
305 | uv run client.py path/to/build/index.js # node server
306 | ```
307 | 
308 | <Note>
309 | If you're continuing the weather tutorial from the quickstart, your command might look something like this: `python client.py .../weather/src/weather/server.py`
310 | </Note>
311 | 
312 | The client will:
313 | 1. Connect to the specified server
314 | 2. List available tools
315 | 3. Start an interactive chat session where you can:
316 |    - Enter queries
317 |    - See tool executions
318 |    - Get responses from Claude
319 | 
320 | Here's an example of what it should look like if connected to the weather server from the quickstart:
321 | 
322 | <Frame>
323 |   <img src="/images/client-claude-cli-python.png" />
324 | </Frame>
325 | 
326 | ## How It Works
327 | 
328 | When you submit a query:
329 | 
330 | 1. The client gets the list of available tools from the server
331 | 2. Your query is sent to Claude along with tool descriptions
332 | 3. Claude decides which tools (if any) to use
333 | 4. The client executes any requested tool calls through the server
334 | 5. Results are sent back to Claude
335 | 6. Claude provides a natural language response
336 | 7. The response is displayed to you
337 | 
338 | ## Best practices
339 | 
340 | 1. **Error Handling**
341 |    - Always wrap tool calls in try-catch blocks
342 |    - Provide meaningful error messages
343 |    - Gracefully handle connection issues
344 | 
345 | 2. **Resource Management**
346 |    - Use `AsyncExitStack` for proper cleanup
347 |    - Close connections when done
348 |    - Handle server disconnections
349 | 
350 | 3. **Security**
351 |    - Store API keys securely in `.env`
352 |    - Validate server responses
353 |    - Be cautious with tool permissions
354 | 
355 | ## Troubleshooting
356 | 
357 | ### Server Path Issues
358 | - Double-check the path to your server script is correct
359 | - Use the absolute path if the relative path isn't working
360 | - For Windows users, make sure to use forward slashes (/) or escaped backslashes (\\) in the path
361 | - Verify the server file has the correct extension (.py for Python or .js for Node.js)
362 | 
363 | Example of correct path usage:
364 | ```bash
365 | # Relative path
366 | uv run client.py ./server/weather.py
367 | 
368 | # Absolute path
369 | uv run client.py /Users/username/projects/mcp-server/weather.py
370 | 
371 | # Windows path (either format works)
372 | uv run client.py C:/projects/mcp-server/weather.py
373 | uv run client.py C:\\projects\\mcp-server\\weather.py
374 | ```
375 | 
376 | ### Response Timing
377 | - The first response might take up to 30 seconds to return
378 | - This is normal and happens while:
379 |   - The server initializes
380 |   - Claude processes the query
381 |   - Tools are being executed
382 | - Subsequent responses are typically faster
383 | - Don't interrupt the process during this initial waiting period
384 | 
385 | ### Common Error Messages
386 | 
387 | If you see:
388 | - `FileNotFoundError`: Check your server path
389 | - `Connection refused`: Ensure the server is running and the path is correct
390 | - `Tool execution failed`: Verify the tool's required environment variables are set
391 | - `Timeout error`: Consider increasing the timeout in your client configuration
392 | 
393 | </Tab>
394 | 
395 | </Tabs>
396 | 
397 | ## Next steps
398 | 
399 | <CardGroup cols={1}>
400 |   <Card
401 |     title="Example servers"
402 |     icon="grid"
403 |     href="/examples"
404 |   >
405 |     Check out our gallery of official MCP servers and implementations
406 |   </Card>
407 |    <Card
408 |     title="Core architecture"
409 |     icon="sitemap"
410 |     href="/docs/concepts/architecture"
411 |   >
412 |     Understand how MCP connects clients, servers, and LLMs
413 |   </Card>
414 | </CardGroup>

/tutorials/building-mcp-with-claude.mdx:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 1 | ---
 2 | title: "Building MCP with Claude"
 3 | description: "Speed up your MCP development with Claude!"
 4 | ---
 5 | 
 6 | This guide will help you use Claude to build custom Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers and clients.
 7 | 
 8 | ## Preparing the documentation
 9 | 
10 | Before starting, gather the necessary documentation to help Claude understand MCP:
11 | 
12 | 1. Visit https://modelcontextprotocol.io/llms-full.txt and copy the full documentation text
13 | 2. Navigate to either the [MCP TypeScript SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/typescript-sdk) or [Python SDK repository](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk)
14 | 3. Copy the README files and other relevant documentation
15 | 4. Paste these documents into your conversation with Claude
16 | 
17 | ## Describing your server
18 | 
19 | Once you've provided the documentation, clearly describe to Claude what kind of server you want to build. Be specific about:
20 | 
21 | - What resources your server will expose
22 | - What tools it will provide
23 | - Any prompts it should offer
24 | - What external systems it needs to interact with
25 | 
26 | For example:
27 | ```
28 | Build an MCP server that:
29 | - Connects to my company's PostgreSQL database
30 | - Exposes table schemas as resources
31 | - Provides tools for running read-only SQL queries
32 | - Includes prompts for common data analysis tasks
33 | ```
34 | 
35 | ## Working with Claude
36 | 
37 | When working with Claude on MCP servers:
38 | 
39 | 1. Start with the core functionality first, then iterate to add more features
40 | 2. Ask Claude to explain any parts of the code you don't understand
41 | 3. Request modifications or improvements as needed
42 | 4. Have Claude help you test the server and handle edge cases
43 | 
44 | Claude can help implement all the key MCP features:
45 | 
46 | - Resource management and exposure
47 | - Tool definitions and implementations
48 | - Prompt templates and handlers
49 | - Error handling and logging
50 | - Connection and transport setup
51 | 
52 | ## Best practices
53 | 
54 | When building MCP servers with Claude:
55 | 
56 | - Break down complex servers into smaller pieces
57 | - Test each component thoroughly before moving on
58 | - Keep security in mind - validate inputs and limit access appropriately
59 | - Document your code well for future maintenance
60 | - Follow MCP protocol specifications carefully
61 | 
62 | ## Next steps
63 | 
64 | After Claude helps you build your server:
65 | 
66 | 1. Review the generated code carefully
67 | 2. Test the server with the MCP Inspector tool
68 | 3. Connect it to Claude.app or other MCP clients
69 | 4. Iterate based on real usage and feedback
70 | 
71 | Remember that Claude can help you modify and improve your server as requirements change over time.
72 | 
73 | Need more guidance? Just ask Claude specific questions about implementing MCP features or troubleshooting issues that arise.---

  1 | # Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
  2 | 
  3 | ## Our Pledge
  4 | 
  5 | We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in our
  6 | community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body
  7 | size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender
  8 | identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status,
  9 | nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity
 10 | and orientation.
 11 | 
 12 | We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming,
 13 | diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.
 14 | 
 15 | ## Our Standards
 16 | 
 17 | Examples of behavior that contributes to a positive environment for our
 18 | community include:
 19 | 
 20 | * Demonstrating empathy and kindness toward other people
 21 | * Being respectful of differing opinions, viewpoints, and experiences
 22 | * Giving and gracefully accepting constructive feedback
 23 | * Accepting responsibility and apologizing to those affected by our mistakes,
 24 |   and learning from the experience
 25 | * Focusing on what is best not just for us as individuals, but for the
 26 |   overall community
 27 | 
 28 | Examples of unacceptable behavior include:
 29 | 
 30 | * The use of sexualized language or imagery, and sexual attention or
 31 |   advances of any kind
 32 | * Trolling, insulting or derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
 33 | * Public or private harassment
 34 | * Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or email
 35 |   address, without their explicit permission
 36 | * Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a
 37 |   professional setting
 38 | 
 39 | ## Enforcement Responsibilities
 40 | 
 41 | Community leaders are responsible for clarifying and enforcing our standards of
 42 | acceptable behavior and will take appropriate and fair corrective action in
 43 | response to any behavior that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive,
 44 | or harmful.
 45 | 
 46 | Community leaders have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject
 47 | comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are
 48 | not aligned to this Code of Conduct, and will communicate reasons for moderation
 49 | decisions when appropriate.
 50 | 
 51 | ## Scope
 52 | 
 53 | This Code of Conduct applies within all community spaces, and also applies when
 54 | an individual is officially representing the community in public spaces.
 55 | Examples of representing our community include using an official e-mail address,
 56 | posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed
 57 | representative at an online or offline event.
 58 | 
 59 | ## Enforcement
 60 | 
 61 | Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be
 62 | reported to the community leaders responsible for enforcement at
 63 | mcp-coc@anthropic.com.
 64 | All complaints will be reviewed and investigated promptly and fairly.
 65 | 
 66 | All community leaders are obligated to respect the privacy and security of the
 67 | reporter of any incident.
 68 | 
 69 | ## Enforcement Guidelines
 70 | 
 71 | Community leaders will follow these Community Impact Guidelines in determining
 72 | the consequences for any action they deem in violation of this Code of Conduct:
 73 | 
 74 | ### 1. Correction
 75 | 
 76 | **Community Impact**: Use of inappropriate language or other behavior deemed
 77 | unprofessional or unwelcome in the community.
 78 | 
 79 | **Consequence**: A private, written warning from community leaders, providing
 80 | clarity around the nature of the violation and an explanation of why the
 81 | behavior was inappropriate. A public apology may be requested.
 82 | 
 83 | ### 2. Warning
 84 | 
 85 | **Community Impact**: A violation through a single incident or series
 86 | of actions.
 87 | 
 88 | **Consequence**: A warning with consequences for continued behavior. No
 89 | interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with
 90 | those enforcing the Code of Conduct, for a specified period of time. This
 91 | includes avoiding interactions in community spaces as well as external channels
 92 | like social media. Violating these terms may lead to a temporary or
 93 | permanent ban.
 94 | 
 95 | ### 3. Temporary Ban
 96 | 
 97 | **Community Impact**: A serious violation of community standards, including
 98 | sustained inappropriate behavior.
 99 | 
100 | **Consequence**: A temporary ban from any sort of interaction or public
101 | communication with the community for a specified period of time. No public or
102 | private interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction
103 | with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, is allowed during this period.
104 | Violating these terms may lead to a permanent ban.
105 | 
106 | ### 4. Permanent Ban
107 | 
108 | **Community Impact**: Demonstrating a pattern of violation of community
109 | standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior,  harassment of an
110 | individual, or aggression toward or disparagement of classes of individuals.
111 | 
112 | **Consequence**: A permanent ban from any sort of public interaction within
113 | the community.
114 | 
115 | ## Attribution
116 | 
117 | This Code of Conduct is adapted from the [Contributor Covenant][homepage],
118 | version 2.0, available at
119 | https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html.
120 | 
121 | Community Impact Guidelines were inspired by [Mozilla's code of conduct
122 | enforcement ladder](https://github.com/mozilla/diversity).
123 | 
124 | [homepage]: https://www.contributor-covenant.org
125 | 
126 | For answers to common questions about this code of conduct, see the FAQ at
127 | https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations are available at
128 | https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

 1 | # Contributing to Model Context Protocol Inspector
 2 | 
 3 | Thanks for your interest in contributing! This guide explains how to get involved.
 4 | 
 5 | ## Getting Started
 6 | 
 7 | 1. Fork the repository and clone it locally
 8 | 2. Install dependencies with `npm install`
 9 | 3. Run `npm run dev` to start both client and server in development mode
10 | 4. Use the web UI at http://localhost:5173 to interact with the inspector
11 | 
12 | ## Development Process & Pull Requests
13 | 
14 | 1. Create a new branch for your changes
15 | 2. Make your changes following existing code style and conventions
16 | 3. Test changes locally
17 | 4. Update documentation as needed
18 | 5. Use clear commit messages explaining your changes
19 | 6. Verify all changes work as expected
20 | 7. Submit a pull request
21 | 8. PRs will be reviewed by maintainers
22 | 
23 | ## Code of Conduct
24 | 
25 | This project follows our [Code of Conduct](CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md). Please read it before contributing.
26 | 
27 | ## Security
28 | 
29 | If you find a security vulnerability, please refer to our [Security Policy](SECURITY.md) for reporting instructions.
30 | 
31 | ## Questions?
32 | 
33 | Feel free to [open an issue](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/mcp-inspector/issues) for questions or create a discussion for general topics.
34 | 
35 | ## License
36 | 
37 | By contributing, you agree that your contributions will be licensed under the MIT license.

/README.md:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 1 | # MCP Inspector
 2 | 
 3 | The MCP inspector is a developer tool for testing and debugging MCP servers.
 4 | 
 5 | ![MCP Inspector Screenshot](mcp-inspector.png)
 6 | 
 7 | ## Running the Inspector
 8 | 
 9 | ### From an MCP server repository
10 | 
11 | To inspect an MCP server implementation, there's no need to clone this repo. Instead, use `npx`. For example, if your server is built at `build/index.js`:
12 | 
13 | ```bash
14 | npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector build/index.js
15 | ```
16 | 
17 | You can also pass arguments along which will get passed as arguments to your MCP server:
18 | 
19 | ```
20 | npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector build/index.js arg1 arg2 ...
21 | ```
22 | 
23 | The inspector runs both a client UI (default port 5173) and an MCP proxy server (default port 3000). Open the client UI in your browser to use the inspector. You can customize the ports if needed:
24 | 
25 | ```bash
26 | CLIENT_PORT=8080 SERVER_PORT=9000 npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector build/index.js
27 | ```
28 | 
29 | For more details on ways to use the inspector, see the [Inspector section of the MCP docs site](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/tools/inspector).
30 | 
31 | ### From this repository
32 | 
33 | If you're working on the inspector itself:
34 | 
35 | Development mode:
36 | 
37 | ```bash
38 | npm run dev
39 | ```
40 | 
41 | Production mode:
42 | 
43 | ```bash
44 | npm run build
45 | npm start
46 | ```
47 | 
48 | ## License
49 | 
50 | This project is licensed under the MIT License—see the [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for details.
51 |

/bin/cli.js:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 1 | #!/usr/bin/env node
 2 | 
 3 | import { resolve, dirname } from "path";
 4 | import { spawnPromise } from "spawn-rx";
 5 | import { fileURLToPath } from "url";
 6 | 
 7 | const __dirname = dirname(fileURLToPath(import.meta.url));
 8 | 
 9 | function delay(ms) {
10 |   return new Promise((resolve) => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
11 | }
12 | 
13 | async function main() {
14 |   // Get command line arguments
15 |   const [, , command, ...mcpServerArgs] = process.argv;
16 | 
17 |   const inspectorServerPath = resolve(
18 |     __dirname,
19 |     "..",
20 |     "server",
21 |     "build",
22 |     "index.js",
23 |   );
24 | 
25 |   // Path to the client entry point
26 |   const inspectorClientPath = resolve(
27 |     __dirname,
28 |     "..",
29 |     "client",
30 |     "bin",
31 |     "cli.js",
32 |   );
33 | 
34 |   const CLIENT_PORT = process.env.CLIENT_PORT ?? "5173";
35 |   const SERVER_PORT = process.env.SERVER_PORT ?? "3000";
36 | 
37 |   console.log("Starting MCP inspector...");
38 | 
39 |   const abort = new AbortController();
40 | 
41 |   let cancelled = false;
42 |   process.on("SIGINT", () => {
43 |     cancelled = true;
44 |     abort.abort();
45 |   });
46 | 
47 |   const server = spawnPromise(
48 |     "node",
49 |     [
50 |       inspectorServerPath,
51 |       ...(command ? [`--env`, command] : []),
52 |       ...(mcpServerArgs ? [`--args=${mcpServerArgs.join(" ")}`] : []),
53 |     ],
54 |     {
55 |       env: { ...process.env, PORT: SERVER_PORT },
56 |       signal: abort.signal,
57 |       echoOutput: true,
58 |     },
59 |   );
60 | 
61 |   const client = spawnPromise("node", [inspectorClientPath], {
62 |     env: { ...process.env, PORT: CLIENT_PORT },
63 |     signal: abort.signal,
64 |     echoOutput: true,
65 |   });
66 | 
67 |   // Make sure our server/client didn't immediately fail
68 |   await Promise.any([server, client, delay(2 * 1000)]);
69 |   const portParam = SERVER_PORT === "3000" ? "" : `?proxyPort=${SERVER_PORT}`;
70 |   console.log(
71 |     `\n🔍 MCP Inspector is up and running at http://localhost:${CLIENT_PORT}${portParam} 🚀`,
72 |   );
73 | 
74 |   try {
75 |     await Promise.any([server, client]);
76 |   } catch (e) {
77 |     if (!cancelled || process.env.DEBUG) throw e;
78 |   }
79 | 
80 |   return 0;
81 | }
82 | 
83 | main()
84 |   .then((_) => process.exit(0))
85 |   .catch((e) => {
86 |     console.error(e);
87 |     process.exit(1);
88 |   });
89 |

 1 | # React + TypeScript + Vite
 2 | 
 3 | This template provides a minimal setup to get React working in Vite with HMR and some ESLint rules.
 4 | 
 5 | Currently, two official plugins are available:
 6 | 
 7 | - [@vitejs/plugin-react](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/main/packages/plugin-react/README.md) uses [Babel](https://babeljs.io/) for Fast Refresh
 8 | - [@vitejs/plugin-react-swc](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react-swc) uses [SWC](https://swc.rs/) for Fast Refresh
 9 | 
10 | ## Expanding the ESLint configuration
11 | 
12 | If you are developing a production application, we recommend updating the configuration to enable type aware lint rules:
13 | 
14 | - Configure the top-level `parserOptions` property like this:
15 | 
16 | ```js
17 | export default tseslint.config({
18 |   languageOptions: {
19 |     // other options...
20 |     parserOptions: {
21 |       project: ["./tsconfig.node.json", "./tsconfig.app.json"],
22 |       tsconfigRootDir: import.meta.dirname,
23 |     },
24 |   },
25 | });
26 | ```
27 | 
28 | - Replace `tseslint.configs.recommended` to `tseslint.configs.recommendedTypeChecked` or `tseslint.configs.strictTypeChecked`
29 | - Optionally add `...tseslint.configs.stylisticTypeChecked`
30 | - Install [eslint-plugin-react](https://github.com/jsx-eslint/eslint-plugin-react) and update the config:
31 | 
32 | ```js
33 | // eslint.config.js
34 | import react from "eslint-plugin-react";
35 | 
36 | export default tseslint.config({
37 |   // Set the react version
38 |   settings: { react: { version: "18.3" } },
39 |   plugins: {
40 |     // Add the react plugin
41 |     react,
42 |   },
43 |   rules: {
44 |     // other rules...
45 |     // Enable its recommended rules
46 |     ...react.configs.recommended.rules,
47 |     ...react.configs["jsx-runtime"].rules,
48 |   },
49 | });
50 | ```

  7 |   CompatibilityCallToolResultSchema,
  8 |   CreateMessageRequestSchema,
  9 |   CreateMessageResult,

 16 |   ListToolsResultSchema,

 18 |   ReadResourceResultSchema,
 19 |   Request,
 20 |   Resource,

 25 |   ServerCapabilitiesSchema,
 26 |   Result,

 28 | import { useCallback, useEffect, useRef, useState } from "react";
 29 | 
 30 | import {
 31 |   Notification,
 32 |   StdErrNotification,
 33 |   StdErrNotificationSchema,
 34 | } from "./lib/notificationTypes";
 35 | 
 36 | import { Tabs, TabsList, TabsTrigger } from "@/components/ui/tabs";
 37 | import {
 38 |   Bell,
 39 |   Files,
 40 |   FolderTree,
 41 |   Hammer,
 42 |   Hash,
 43 |   MessageSquare,
 44 | } from "lucide-react";

 46 | import { toast } from "react-toastify";
 47 | import { z, type ZodType } from "zod";
 48 | import "./App.css";
 49 | import ConsoleTab from "./components/ConsoleTab";
 50 | import HistoryAndNotifications from "./components/History";
 51 | import PingTab from "./components/PingTab";
 52 | import PromptsTab, { Prompt } from "./components/PromptsTab";
 53 | import ResourcesTab from "./components/ResourcesTab";
 54 | import RootsTab from "./components/RootsTab";
 55 | import SamplingTab, { PendingRequest } from "./components/SamplingTab";
 56 | import Sidebar from "./components/Sidebar";
 57 | import ToolsTab from "./components/ToolsTab";
 58 | 
 59 | type ServerCapabilities = z.infer<typeof ServerCapabilitiesSchema>;
 60 | 
 61 | const DEFAULT_REQUEST_TIMEOUT_MSEC = 10000;
 62 | 
 63 | const params = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
 64 | const PROXY_PORT = params.get("proxyPort") ?? "3000";
 65 | const REQUEST_TIMEOUT =
 66 |   parseInt(params.get("timeout") ?? "") || DEFAULT_REQUEST_TIMEOUT_MSEC;
 67 | const PROXY_SERVER_URL = `http://localhost:${PROXY_PORT}`;
 68 | 
 69 | const App = () => {
 70 |   const [connectionStatus, setConnectionStatus] = useState<
 71 |     "disconnected" | "connected" | "error"
 72 |   >("disconnected");
 73 |   const [serverCapabilities, setServerCapabilities] = useState<ServerCapabilities | null>(null);
 74 |   const [resources, setResources] = useState<Resource[]>([]);
 75 |   const [resourceTemplates, setResourceTemplates] = useState<
 76 |     ResourceTemplate[]
 77 |   >([]);
 78 |   const [resourceContent, setResourceContent] = useState<string>("");
 79 |   const [prompts, setPrompts] = useState<Prompt[]>([]);
 80 |   const [promptContent, setPromptContent] = useState<string>("");
 81 |   const [tools, setTools] = useState<Tool[]>([]);
 82 |   const [toolResult, setToolResult] =
 83 |     useState<CompatibilityCallToolResult | null>(null);
 84 |   const [errors, setErrors] = useState<Record<string, string | null>>({
 85 |     resources: null,
 86 |     prompts: null,
 87 |     tools: null,
 88 |   });
 89 |   const [command, setCommand] = useState<string>(() => {
 90 |     return localStorage.getItem("lastCommand") || "mcp-server-everything";
 91 |   });
 92 |   const [args, setArgs] = useState<string>(() => {
 93 |     return localStorage.getItem("lastArgs") || "";
 94 |   });
 95 | 
 96 |   const [sseUrl, setSseUrl] = useState<string>("http://localhost:3001/sse");
 97 |   const [transportType, setTransportType] = useState<"stdio" | "sse">("stdio");
 98 |   const [requestHistory, setRequestHistory] = useState<
 99 |     { request: string; response?: string }[]
100 |   >([]);
101 |   const [mcpClient, setMcpClient] = useState<Client | null>(null);
102 |   const [notifications, setNotifications] = useState<ServerNotification[]>([]);
103 |   const [stdErrNotifications, setStdErrNotifications] = useState<
104 |     StdErrNotification[]
105 |   >([]);
106 |   const [roots, setRoots] = useState<Root[]>([]);
107 |   const [env, setEnv] = useState<Record<string, string>>({});
108 | 
109 |   const [pendingSampleRequests, setPendingSampleRequests] = useState<
110 |     Array<
111 |       PendingRequest & {
112 |         resolve: (result: CreateMessageResult) => void;
113 |         reject: (error: Error) => void;
114 |       }
115 |     >
116 |   >([]);
117 |   const nextRequestId = useRef(0);
118 |   const rootsRef = useRef<Root[]>([]);
119 | 
120 |   const handleApproveSampling = (id: number, result: CreateMessageResult) => {
121 |     setPendingSampleRequests((prev) => {
122 |       const request = prev.find((r) => r.id === id);
123 |       request?.resolve(result);
124 |       return prev.filter((r) => r.id !== id);
125 |     });
126 |   };
127 | 
128 |   const handleRejectSampling = (id: number) => {
129 |     setPendingSampleRequests((prev) => {
130 |       const request = prev.find((r) => r.id === id);
131 |       request?.reject(new Error("Sampling request rejected"));
132 |       return prev.filter((r) => r.id !== id);
133 |     });
134 |   };
135 | 
136 |   const [selectedResource, setSelectedResource] = useState<Resource | null>(
137 |     null,
138 |   );
139 |   const [selectedPrompt, setSelectedPrompt] = useState<Prompt | null>(null);
140 |   const [selectedTool, setSelectedTool] = useState<Tool | null>(null);
141 |   const [nextResourceCursor, setNextResourceCursor] = useState<
142 |     string | undefined
143 |   >();
144 |   const [nextResourceTemplateCursor, setNextResourceTemplateCursor] = useState<
145 |     string | undefined
146 |   >();
147 |   const [nextPromptCursor, setNextPromptCursor] = useState<
148 |     string | undefined
149 |   >();
150 |   const [nextToolCursor, setNextToolCursor] = useState<string | undefined>();
151 |   const progressTokenRef = useRef(0);
152 |   const [historyPaneHeight, setHistoryPaneHeight] = useState<number>(300);
153 |   const [isDragging, setIsDragging] = useState(false);
154 |   const dragStartY = useRef<number>(0);
155 |   const dragStartHeight = useRef<number>(0);
156 | 
157 |   const handleDragStart = useCallback(
158 |     (e: React.MouseEvent) => {
159 |       setIsDragging(true);
160 |       dragStartY.current = e.clientY;
161 |       dragStartHeight.current = historyPaneHeight;
162 |       document.body.style.userSelect = "none";
163 |     },
164 |     [historyPaneHeight],
165 |   );
166 | 
167 |   const handleDragMove = useCallback(
168 |     (e: MouseEvent) => {
169 |       if (!isDragging) return;
170 |       const deltaY = dragStartY.current - e.clientY;
171 |       const newHeight = Math.max(
172 |         100,
173 |         Math.min(800, dragStartHeight.current + deltaY),
174 |       );
175 |       setHistoryPaneHeight(newHeight);
176 |     },
177 |     [isDragging],
178 |   );
179 | 
180 |   const handleDragEnd = useCallback(() => {
181 |     setIsDragging(false);
182 |     document.body.style.userSelect = "";
183 |   }, []);
184 | 
185 |   useEffect(() => {
186 |     if (isDragging) {
187 |       window.addEventListener("mousemove", handleDragMove);
188 |       window.addEventListener("mouseup", handleDragEnd);
189 |       return () => {
190 |         window.removeEventListener("mousemove", handleDragMove);
191 |         window.removeEventListener("mouseup", handleDragEnd);
192 |       };
193 |     }
194 |   }, [isDragging, handleDragMove, handleDragEnd]);
195 | 
196 |   useEffect(() => {
197 |     localStorage.setItem("lastCommand", command);
198 |   }, [command]);
199 | 
200 |   useEffect(() => {
201 |     localStorage.setItem("lastArgs", args);
202 |   }, [args]);
203 | 
204 |   useEffect(() => {
205 |     fetch(`${PROXY_SERVER_URL}/config`)
206 |       .then((response) => response.json())
207 |       .then((data) => {
208 |         setEnv(data.defaultEnvironment);
209 |         if (data.defaultCommand) {
210 |           setCommand(data.defaultCommand);
211 |         }
212 |         if (data.defaultArgs) {
213 |           setArgs(data.defaultArgs);
214 |         }
215 |       })
216 |       .catch((error) =>
217 |         console.error("Error fetching default environment:", error),
218 |       );
219 |   }, []);
220 | 
221 |   useEffect(() => {
222 |     rootsRef.current = roots;
223 |   }, [roots]);
224 | 
225 |   useEffect(() => {
226 |     if (!window.location.hash) {
227 |       window.location.hash = "resources";
228 |     }
229 |   }, []);
230 | 
231 |   const pushHistory = (request: object, response?: object) => {
232 |     setRequestHistory((prev) => [
233 |       ...prev,
234 |       {
235 |         request: JSON.stringify(request),
236 |         response: response !== undefined ? JSON.stringify(response) : undefined,
237 |       },
238 |     ]);
239 |   };
240 | 
241 |   const clearError = (tabKey: keyof typeof errors) => {
242 |     setErrors((prev) => ({ ...prev, [tabKey]: null }));
243 |   };
244 | 
245 |   const makeRequest = async <T extends ZodType<object>>(
246 |     request: ClientRequest,
247 |     schema: T,
248 |     tabKey?: keyof typeof errors,
249 |   ) => {
250 |     if (!mcpClient) {
251 |       throw new Error("MCP client not connected");
252 |     }
253 | 
254 |     try {
255 |       const abortController = new AbortController();
256 |       const timeoutId = setTimeout(() => {
257 |         abortController.abort("Request timed out");
258 |       }, REQUEST_TIMEOUT);
259 | 
260 |       let response;
261 |       try {
262 |         response = await mcpClient.request(request, schema, {
263 |           signal: abortController.signal,
264 |         });
265 |         pushHistory(request, response);
266 |       } catch (error) {
267 |         const errorMessage = error instanceof Error ? error.message : String(error);
268 |         pushHistory(request, { error: errorMessage });
269 |         throw error;
270 |       } finally {
271 |         clearTimeout(timeoutId);
272 |       }
273 | 
274 |       if (tabKey !== undefined) {
275 |         clearError(tabKey);
276 |       }
277 | 
278 |       return response;
279 |     } catch (e: unknown) {
280 |       const errorString = (e as Error).message ?? String(e);
281 |       if (tabKey === undefined) {
282 |         toast.error(errorString);
283 |       } else {
284 |         setErrors((prev) => ({
285 |           ...prev,
286 |           [tabKey]: errorString,
287 |         }));
288 |       }
289 | 
290 |       throw e;
291 |     }
292 |   };
293 | 
294 |   const sendNotification = async (notification: ClientNotification) => {
295 |     if (!mcpClient) {
296 |       throw new Error("MCP client not connected");
297 |     }
298 | 
299 |     try {
300 |       await mcpClient.notification(notification);
301 |       pushHistory(notification);
302 |     } catch (e: unknown) {
303 |       toast.error((e as Error).message ?? String(e));
304 |       throw e;
305 |     }
306 |   };
307 | 
308 |   const listResources = async () => {
309 |     const response = await makeRequest(
310 |       {
311 |         method: "resources/list" as const,
312 |         params: nextResourceCursor ? { cursor: nextResourceCursor } : {},
313 |       },
314 |       ListResourcesResultSchema,
315 |       "resources",
316 |     );
317 |     setResources(resources.concat(response.resources ?? []));
318 |     setNextResourceCursor(response.nextCursor);
319 |   };
320 | 
321 |   const listResourceTemplates = async () => {
322 |     const response = await makeRequest(
323 |       {
324 |         method: "resources/templates/list" as const,
325 |         params: nextResourceTemplateCursor
326 |           ? { cursor: nextResourceTemplateCursor }
327 |           : {},
328 |       },
329 |       ListResourceTemplatesResultSchema,
330 |       "resources",
331 |     );
332 |     setResourceTemplates(
333 |       resourceTemplates.concat(response.resourceTemplates ?? []),
334 |     );
335 |     setNextResourceTemplateCursor(response.nextCursor);
336 |   };
337 | 
338 |   const readResource = async (uri: string) => {
339 |     const response = await makeRequest(
340 |       {
341 |         method: "resources/read" as const,
342 |         params: { uri },
343 |       },
344 |       ReadResourceResultSchema,
345 |       "resources",
346 |     );
347 |     setResourceContent(JSON.stringify(response, null, 2));
348 |   };
349 | 
350 |   const listPrompts = async () => {
351 |     const response = await makeRequest(
352 |       {
353 |         method: "prompts/list" as const,
354 |         params: nextPromptCursor ? { cursor: nextPromptCursor } : {},
355 |       },
356 |       ListPromptsResultSchema,
357 |       "prompts",
358 |     );
359 |     setPrompts(response.prompts);
360 |     setNextPromptCursor(response.nextCursor);
361 |   };
362 | 
363 |   const getPrompt = async (name: string, args: Record<string, string> = {}) => {
364 |     const response = await makeRequest(
365 |       {
366 |         method: "prompts/get" as const,
367 |         params: { name, arguments: args },
368 |       },
369 |       GetPromptResultSchema,
370 |       "prompts",
371 |     );
372 |     setPromptContent(JSON.stringify(response, null, 2));
373 |   };
374 | 
375 |   const listTools = async () => {
376 |     const response = await makeRequest(
377 |       {
378 |         method: "tools/list" as const,
379 |         params: nextToolCursor ? { cursor: nextToolCursor } : {},
380 |       },
381 |       ListToolsResultSchema,
382 |       "tools",
383 |     );
384 |     setTools(response.tools);
385 |     setNextToolCursor(response.nextCursor);
386 |   };
387 | 
388 |   const callTool = async (name: string, params: Record<string, unknown>) => {
389 |     const response = await makeRequest(
390 |       {
391 |         method: "tools/call" as const,
392 |         params: {
393 |           name,
394 |           arguments: params,
395 |           _meta: {
396 |             progressToken: progressTokenRef.current++,
397 |           },
398 |         },
399 |       },
400 |       CompatibilityCallToolResultSchema,
401 |       "tools",
402 |     );
403 |     setToolResult(response);
404 |   };
405 | 
406 |   const handleRootsChange = async () => {
407 |     await sendNotification({ method: "notifications/roots/list_changed" });
408 |   };
409 | 
410 |   const connectMcpServer = async () => {
411 |     try {
412 |       const client = new Client<Request, Notification, Result>(
413 |         {
414 |           name: "mcp-inspector",
415 |           version: "0.0.1",
416 |         },
417 |         {
418 |           capabilities: {
419 |             // Support all client capabilities since we're an inspector tool
420 |             sampling: {},
421 |             roots: {
422 |               listChanged: true,
423 |             },
424 |           },
425 |         },
426 |       );
427 | 
428 |       const backendUrl = new URL(`${PROXY_SERVER_URL}/sse`);
429 | 
430 |       backendUrl.searchParams.append("transportType", transportType);
431 |       if (transportType === "stdio") {
432 |         backendUrl.searchParams.append("command", command);
433 |         backendUrl.searchParams.append("args", args);
434 |         backendUrl.searchParams.append("env", JSON.stringify(env));
435 |       } else {
436 |         backendUrl.searchParams.append("url", sseUrl);
437 |       }
438 | 
439 |       const clientTransport = new SSEClientTransport(backendUrl);
440 |       client.setNotificationHandler(
441 |         ProgressNotificationSchema,
442 |         (notification) => {
443 |           setNotifications((prevNotifications) => [
444 |             ...prevNotifications,
445 |             notification,
446 |           ]);
447 |         },
448 |       );
449 | 
450 |       client.setNotificationHandler(
451 |         StdErrNotificationSchema,
452 |         (notification) => {
453 |           setStdErrNotifications((prevErrorNotifications) => [
454 |             ...prevErrorNotifications,
455 |             notification,
456 |           ]);
457 |         },
458 |       );
459 | 
460 |       await client.connect(clientTransport);
461 | 
462 |       const capabilities = client.getServerCapabilities();
463 |       setServerCapabilities(capabilities ?? null);
464 | 
465 |       client.setRequestHandler(CreateMessageRequestSchema, (request) => {
466 |         return new Promise<CreateMessageResult>((resolve, reject) => {
467 |           setPendingSampleRequests((prev) => [
468 |             ...prev,
469 |             { id: nextRequestId.current++, request, resolve, reject },
470 |           ]);
471 |         });
472 |       });
473 | 
474 |       client.setRequestHandler(ListRootsRequestSchema, async () => {
475 |         return { roots: rootsRef.current };
476 |       });
477 | 
478 |       setMcpClient(client);
479 |       setConnectionStatus("connected");
480 |     } catch (e) {
481 |       console.error(e);
482 |       setConnectionStatus("error");
483 |     }
484 |   };
485 | 
486 |   return (
487 |     <div className="flex h-screen bg-background">
488 |       <Sidebar
489 |         connectionStatus={connectionStatus}
490 |         transportType={transportType}
491 |         setTransportType={setTransportType}
492 |         command={command}
493 |         setCommand={setCommand}
494 |         args={args}
495 |         setArgs={setArgs}
496 |         sseUrl={sseUrl}
497 |         setSseUrl={setSseUrl}
498 |         env={env}
499 |         setEnv={setEnv}
500 |         onConnect={connectMcpServer}

  1 | import { ServerNotification } from "@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/types.js";
  2 | import { Copy } from "lucide-react";

  4 | 
  5 | const HistoryAndNotifications = ({
  6 |   requestHistory,
  7 |   serverNotifications,
  8 | }: {
  9 |   requestHistory: Array<{ request: string; response?: string }>;
 10 |   serverNotifications: ServerNotification[];
 11 | }) => {
 12 |   const [expandedRequests, setExpandedRequests] = useState<{
 13 |     [key: number]: boolean;
 14 |   }>({});

 16 |     [key: number]: boolean;
 17 |   }>({});
 18 |

 21 |   };

 25 |   };
 26 |

 29 |   };
 30 | 
 31 |   return (
 32 |     <div className="bg-card overflow-hidden flex h-full">

 38 |           <ul className="space-y-3">
 39 |             {requestHistory
 40 |               .slice()
 41 |               .reverse()
 42 |               .map((request, index) => (

 45 |                   className="text-sm text-foreground bg-secondary p-2 rounded"

 52 |                   >

 54 |                       {requestHistory.length - index}.{" "}
 55 |                       {JSON.parse(request.request).method}
 56 |                     </span>
 57 |                     <span>
 58 |                       {expandedRequests[requestHistory.length - 1 - index]
 59 |                         ? "▼"
 60 |                         : "▶"}
 61 |                     </span>
 62 |                   </div>
 63 |                   {expandedRequests[requestHistory.length - 1 - index] && (
 64 |                     <>
 65 |                       <div className="mt-2">
 66 |                         <div className="flex justify-between items-center mb-1">
 67 |                           <span className="font-semibold text-blue-600">
 68 |                             Request:
 69 |                           </span>
 70 |                           <button
 71 |                             onClick={() => copyToClipboard(request.request)}
 72 |                             className="text-blue-500 hover:text-blue-700"
 73 |                           >
 74 |                             <Copy size={16} />
 75 |                           </button>
 76 |                         </div>
 77 |                         <pre className="whitespace-pre-wrap break-words bg-background p-2 rounded">
 78 |                           {JSON.stringify(JSON.parse(request.request), null, 2)}
 79 |                         </pre>
 80 |                       </div>
 81 |                       {request.response && (
 82 |                         <div className="mt-2">
 83 |                           <div className="flex justify-between items-center mb-1">
 84 |                             <span className="font-semibold text-green-600">
 85 |                               Response:
 86 |                             </span>
 87 |                             <button
 88 |                               onClick={() => copyToClipboard(request.response!)}
 89 |                               className="text-blue-500 hover:text-blue-700"
 90 |                             >
 91 |                               <Copy size={16} />
 92 |                             </button>
 93 |                           </div>
 94 |                           <pre className="whitespace-pre-wrap break-words bg-background p-2 rounded">
 95 |                             {JSON.stringify(
 96 |                               JSON.parse(request.response),
 97 |                               null,
 98 |                               2,
 99 |                             )}
100 |                           </pre>
101 |                         </div>
102 |                       )}
103 |                     </>
104 |                   )}
105 |                 </li>
106 |               ))}
107 |           </ul>
108 |         )}
109 |       </div>
110 |       <div className="flex-1 overflow-y-auto p-4">
111 |         <h2 className="text-lg font-semibold mb-4">Server Notifications</h2>
112 |         {serverNotifications.length === 0 ? (

114 |         ) : (
115 |           <ul className="space-y-3">
116 |             {serverNotifications
117 |               .slice()
118 |               .reverse()
119 |               .map((notification, index) => (

122 |                   className="text-sm text-foreground bg-secondary p-2 rounded"
123 |                 >
124 |                   <div

126 |                     onClick={() => toggleNotificationExpansion(index)}
127 |                   >
128 |                     <span className="font-mono">
129 |                       {serverNotifications.length - index}.{" "}
130 |                       {notification.method}
131 |                     </span>
132 |                     <span>{expandedNotifications[index] ? "▼" : "▶"}</span>
133 |                   </div>
134 |                   {expandedNotifications[index] && (
135 |                     <div className="mt-2">
136 |                       <div className="flex justify-between items-center mb-1">
137 |                         <span className="font-semibold text-purple-600">
138 |                           Details:
139 |                         </span>
140 |                         <button
141 |                           onClick={() =>
142 |                             copyToClipboard(JSON.stringify(notification))
143 |                           }
144 |                           className="text-blue-500 hover:text-blue-700"
145 |                         >
146 |                           <Copy size={16} />
147 |                         </button>
148 |                       </div>
149 |                       <pre className="whitespace-pre-wrap break-words bg-background p-2 rounded">
150 |                         {JSON.stringify(notification, null, 2)}
151 |                       </pre>
152 |                     </div>
153 |                   )}
154 |                 </li>
155 |               ))}
156 |           </ul>
157 |         )}
158 |       </div>
159 |     </div>
160 |   );
161 | };
162 | 
163 | export default HistoryAndNotifications;

  1 | import { Alert, AlertDescription, AlertTitle } from "@/components/ui/alert";
  2 | import { Button } from "@/components/ui/button";
  3 | import { Input } from "@/components/ui/input";
  4 | import { Label } from "@/components/ui/label";
  5 | import { TabsContent } from "@/components/ui/tabs";
  6 | import { Textarea } from "@/components/ui/textarea";
  7 | import { ListPromptsResult } from "@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/types.js";
  8 | import { AlertCircle } from "lucide-react";
  9 | import { useState } from "react";
 10 | import ListPane from "./ListPane";
 11 | 
 12 | export type Prompt = {
 13 |   name: string;
 14 |   description?: string;
 15 |   arguments?: {
 16 |     name: string;
 17 |     description?: string;
 18 |     required?: boolean;
 19 |   }[];
 20 | };
 21 | 
 22 | const PromptsTab = ({
 23 |   prompts,
 24 |   listPrompts,
 25 |   clearPrompts,
 26 |   getPrompt,
 27 |   selectedPrompt,
 28 |   setSelectedPrompt,
 29 |   promptContent,
 30 |   nextCursor,
 31 |   error,
 32 | }: {
 33 |   prompts: Prompt[];
 34 |   listPrompts: () => void;
 35 |   clearPrompts: () => void;
 36 |   getPrompt: (name: string, args: Record<string, string>) => void;
 37 |   selectedPrompt: Prompt | null;
 38 |   setSelectedPrompt: (prompt: Prompt) => void;
 39 |   promptContent: string;
 40 |   nextCursor: ListPromptsResult["nextCursor"];
 41 |   error: string | null;
 42 | }) => {
 43 |   const [promptArgs, setPromptArgs] = useState<Record<string, string>>({});
 44 | 
 45 |   const handleInputChange = (argName: string, value: string) => {
 46 |     setPromptArgs((prev) => ({ ...prev, [argName]: value }));
 47 |   };
 48 | 
 49 |   const handleGetPrompt = () => {
 50 |     if (selectedPrompt) {
 51 |       getPrompt(selectedPrompt.name, promptArgs);
 52 |     }
 53 |   };
 54 | 
 55 |   return (
 56 |     <TabsContent value="prompts" className="grid grid-cols-2 gap-4">
 57 |       <ListPane
 58 |         items={prompts}
 59 |         listItems={listPrompts}
 60 |         clearItems={clearPrompts}
 61 |         setSelectedItem={(prompt) => {
 62 |           setSelectedPrompt(prompt);
 63 |           setPromptArgs({});
 64 |         }}
 65 |         renderItem={(prompt) => (
 66 |           <>
 67 |             <span className="flex-1">{prompt.name}</span>
 68 |             <span className="text-sm text-gray-500">{prompt.description}</span>
 69 |           </>
 70 |         )}
 71 |         title="Prompts"
 72 |         buttonText={nextCursor ? "List More Prompts" : "List Prompts"}
 73 |         isButtonDisabled={!nextCursor && prompts.length > 0}
 74 |       />
 75 | 
 76 |       <div className="bg-card rounded-lg shadow">
 77 |         <div className="p-4 border-b border-gray-200">
 78 |           <h3 className="font-semibold">
 79 |             {selectedPrompt ? selectedPrompt.name : "Select a prompt"}
 80 |           </h3>
 81 |         </div>
 82 |         <div className="p-4">
 83 |           {error ? (
 84 |             <Alert variant="destructive">
 85 |               <AlertCircle className="h-4 w-4" />
 86 |               <AlertTitle>Error</AlertTitle>
 87 |               <AlertDescription>{error}</AlertDescription>
 88 |             </Alert>
 89 |           ) : selectedPrompt ? (
 90 |             <div className="space-y-4">
 91 |               {selectedPrompt.description && (
 92 |                 <p className="text-sm text-gray-600">
 93 |                   {selectedPrompt.description}
 94 |                 </p>
 95 |               )}
 96 |               {selectedPrompt.arguments?.map((arg) => (
 97 |                 <div key={arg.name}>
 98 |                   <Label htmlFor={arg.name}>{arg.name}</Label>
 99 |                   <Input
100 |                     id={arg.name}
101 |                     placeholder={`Enter ${arg.name}`}
102 |                     value={promptArgs[arg.name] || ""}
103 |                     onChange={(e) =>
104 |                       handleInputChange(arg.name, e.target.value)
105 |                     }
106 |                   />
107 |                   {arg.description && (
108 |                     <p className="text-xs text-gray-500 mt-1">
109 |                       {arg.description}
110 |                       {arg.required && (
111 |                         <span className="text-xs mt-1 ml-1">(Required)</span>
112 |                       )}
113 |                     </p>
114 |                   )}
115 |                 </div>
116 |               ))}
117 |               <Button onClick={handleGetPrompt} className="w-full">
118 |                 Get Prompt
119 |               </Button>
120 |               {promptContent && (
121 |                 <Textarea
122 |                   value={promptContent}
123 |                   readOnly
124 |                   className="h-64 font-mono"
125 |                 />
126 |               )}
127 |             </div>
128 |           ) : (
129 |             <Alert>
130 |               <AlertDescription>
131 |                 Select a prompt from the list to view and use it
132 |               </AlertDescription>
133 |             </Alert>
134 |           )}
135 |         </div>
136 |       </div>
137 |     </TabsContent>
138 |   );
139 | };
140 | 
141 | export default PromptsTab;
142 |

 12 | import ListPane from "./ListPane";
 13 | import { useState } from "react";
 14 | 
 15 | const ResourcesTab = ({
 16 |   resources,
 17 |   resourceTemplates,
 18 |   listResources,
 19 |   clearResources,
 20 |   listResourceTemplates,
 21 |   clearResourceTemplates,
 22 |   readResource,
 23 |   selectedResource,
 24 |   setSelectedResource,
 25 |   resourceContent,
 26 |   nextCursor,
 27 |   nextTemplateCursor,
 28 |   error,
 29 | }: {
 30 |   resources: Resource[];
 31 |   resourceTemplates: ResourceTemplate[];
 32 |   listResources: () => void;
 33 |   clearResources: () => void;
 34 |   listResourceTemplates: () => void;
 35 |   clearResourceTemplates: () => void;
 36 |   readResource: (uri: string) => void;
 37 |   selectedResource: Resource | null;
 38 |   setSelectedResource: (resource: Resource | null) => void;
 39 |   resourceContent: string;
 40 |   nextCursor: ListResourcesResult["nextCursor"];
 41 |   nextTemplateCursor: ListResourceTemplatesResult["nextCursor"];
 42 |   error: string | null;
 43 | }) => {
 44 |   const [selectedTemplate, setSelectedTemplate] =
 45 |     useState<ResourceTemplate | null>(null);
 46 |   const [templateValues, setTemplateValues] = useState<Record<string, string>>(
 47 |     {},
 48 |   );
 49 | 
 50 |   const fillTemplate = (
 51 |     template: string,
 52 |     values: Record<string, string>,
 53 |   ): string => {
 54 |     return template.replace(
 55 |       /{([^}]+)}/g,
 56 |       (_, key) => values[key] || `{${key}}`,
 57 |     );
 58 |   };
 59 | 
 60 |   const handleReadTemplateResource = () => {
 61 |     if (selectedTemplate) {
 62 |       const uri = fillTemplate(selectedTemplate.uriTemplate, templateValues);
 63 |       readResource(uri);
 64 |       setSelectedTemplate(null);
 65 |       // We don't have the full Resource object here, so we create a partial one
 66 |       setSelectedResource({ uri, name: uri } as Resource);
 67 |     }
 68 |   };
 69 | 
 70 |   return (
 71 |     <TabsContent value="resources" className="grid grid-cols-3 gap-4">
 72 |       <ListPane
 73 |         items={resources}
 74 |         listItems={listResources}
 75 |         clearItems={clearResources}
 76 |         setSelectedItem={(resource) => {
 77 |           setSelectedResource(resource);
 78 |           readResource(resource.uri);
 79 |           setSelectedTemplate(null);
 80 |         }}

 1 | import { Alert, AlertDescription } from "@/components/ui/alert";

 7 | 
 8 | const RootsTab = ({

13 |   roots: Root[];

15 |   onRootsChange: () => void;
16 | }) => {
17 |   const addRoot = () => {
18 |     setRoots((currentRoots) => [...currentRoots, { uri: "file://", name: "" }]);
19 |   };
20 | 
21 |   const removeRoot = (index: number) => {
22 |     setRoots((currentRoots) => currentRoots.filter((_, i) => i !== index));
23 |   };
24 | 
25 |   const updateRoot = (index: number, field: keyof Root, value: string) => {
26 |     setRoots((currentRoots) =>
27 |       currentRoots.map((root, i) =>
28 |         i === index ? { ...root, [field]: value } : root,
29 |       ),
30 |     );
31 |   };
32 | 
33 |   const handleSave = () => {
34 |     onRootsChange();
35 |   };
36 | 
37 |   return (
38 |     <TabsContent value="roots" className="space-y-4">
39 |       <Alert>
40 |         <AlertDescription>
41 |           Configure the root directories that the server can access
42 |         </AlertDescription>
43 |       </Alert>

46 |         <div key={index} className="flex gap-2 items-center">
47 |           <Input

50 |             onChange={(e) => updateRoot(index, "uri", e.target.value)}
51 |             className="flex-1"
52 |           />
53 |           <Button
54 |             variant="destructive"
55 |             size="sm"
56 |             onClick={() => removeRoot(index)}
57 |           >
58 |             <Minus className="h-4 w-4" />
59 |           </Button>
60 |         </div>
61 |       ))}
62 | 
63 |       <div className="flex gap-2">
64 |         <Button variant="outline" onClick={addRoot}>
65 |           <Plus className="h-4 w-4 mr-2" />
66 |           Add Root
67 |         </Button>
68 |         <Button onClick={handleSave}>
69 |           <Save className="h-4 w-4 mr-2" />
70 |           Save Changes
71 |         </Button>
72 |       </div>
73 |     </TabsContent>
74 |   );
75 | };

77 | export default RootsTab;

173 |                             })
174 |                           }
175 |                           className="mt-1"
176 |                         />
177 |                       ) : (

179 |                           // @ts-expect-error value type is currently unknown
180 |                           type={value.type === "number" ? "number" : "text"}
181 |                           id={key}
182 |                           name={key}
183 |                           // @ts-expect-error value type is currently unknown
184 |                           placeholder={value.description}

194 |                           }
195 |                           className="mt-1"
196 |                         />
197 |                       )
198 |                     }

200 |                 ),
201 |               )}
202 |               <Button onClick={() => callTool(selectedTool.name, params)}>

204 |                 Run Tool

 1 | import { useCallback, useEffect, useState } from "react";
 2 | 
 3 | type Theme = "light" | "dark" | "system";
 4 | 
 5 | const useTheme = (): [Theme, (mode: Theme) => void] => {
 6 |   const [theme, setTheme] = useState<Theme>(() => {
 7 |     const savedTheme = localStorage.getItem("theme") as Theme;
 8 |     return savedTheme || "system";
 9 |   });
10 | 
11 |   useEffect(() => {
12 |     const darkModeMediaQuery = window.matchMedia(
13 |       "(prefers-color-scheme: dark)",
14 |     );
15 |     const handleDarkModeChange = (e: MediaQueryListEvent) => {
16 |       if (theme === "system") {
17 |         updateDocumentTheme(e.matches ? "dark" : "light");
18 |       }
19 |     };
20 | 
21 |     const updateDocumentTheme = (newTheme: "light" | "dark") => {
22 |       document.documentElement.classList.toggle("dark", newTheme === "dark");
23 |     };
24 | 
25 |     // Set initial theme based on current mode
26 |     if (theme === "system") {
27 |       updateDocumentTheme(darkModeMediaQuery.matches ? "dark" : "light");
28 |     } else {
29 |       updateDocumentTheme(theme);
30 |     }
31 | 
32 |     darkModeMediaQuery.addEventListener("change", handleDarkModeChange);
33 | 
34 |     return () => {
35 |       darkModeMediaQuery.removeEventListener("change", handleDarkModeChange);
36 |     };
37 |   }, [theme]);
38 | 
39 |   return [
40 |     theme,
41 |     useCallback((newTheme: Theme) => {
42 |       setTheme(newTheme);
43 |       localStorage.setItem("theme", newTheme);
44 |       if (newTheme !== "system") {
45 |         document.documentElement.classList.toggle("dark", newTheme === "dark");
46 |       }
47 |     }, []),
48 |   ];
49 | };
50 | 
51 | export default useTheme;
52 |

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1 | #!/usr/bin/env node
  2 | 
  3 | import cors from "cors";
  4 | import EventSource from "eventsource";
  5 | import { parseArgs } from "node:util";
  6 | import { parse as shellParseArgs } from "shell-quote";
  7 | 
  8 | import { SSEClientTransport } from "@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/client/sse.js";
  9 | import {
 10 |   StdioClientTransport,
 11 |   getDefaultEnvironment,
 12 | } from "@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/client/stdio.js";
 13 | import { SSEServerTransport } from "@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/server/sse.js";
 14 | import express from "express";
 15 | import mcpProxy from "./mcpProxy.js";
 16 | import { findActualExecutable } from "spawn-rx";
 17 | 
 18 | // Polyfill EventSource for an SSE client in Node.js
 19 | // eslint-disable-next-line @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any
 20 | (global as any).EventSource = EventSource;
 21 | 
 22 | const { values } = parseArgs({
 23 |   args: process.argv.slice(2),
 24 |   options: {
 25 |     env: { type: "string", default: "" },
 26 |     args: { type: "string", default: "" },
 27 |   },
 28 | });
 29 | 
 30 | const app = express();
 31 | app.use(cors());
 32 | 
 33 | let webAppTransports: SSEServerTransport[] = [];
 34 | 
 35 | const createTransport = async (query: express.Request["query"]) => {
 36 |   console.log("Query parameters:", query);
 37 | 
 38 |   const transportType = query.transportType as string;
 39 | 
 40 |   if (transportType === "stdio") {
 41 |     const command = query.command as string;
 42 |     const origArgs = shellParseArgs(query.args as string) as string[];
 43 |     const env = query.env ? JSON.parse(query.env as string) : undefined;
 44 | 
 45 |     const { cmd, args } = findActualExecutable(command, origArgs);
 46 | 
 47 |     console.log(
 48 |       `Stdio transport: command=${cmd}, args=${args}, env=${JSON.stringify(env)}`,
 49 |     );
 50 | 
 51 |     const transport = new StdioClientTransport({
 52 |       command: cmd,
 53 |       args,
 54 |       env,
 55 |       stderr: "pipe",
 56 |     });
 57 | 
 58 |     await transport.start();
 59 | 
 60 |     console.log("Spawned stdio transport");
 61 |     return transport;
 62 |   } else if (transportType === "sse") {
 63 |     const url = query.url as string;
 64 |     console.log(`SSE transport: url=${url}`);
 65 | 
 66 |     const transport = new SSEClientTransport(new URL(url));
 67 |     await transport.start();
 68 | 
 69 |     console.log("Connected to SSE transport");
 70 |     return transport;
 71 |   } else {
 72 |     console.error(`Invalid transport type: ${transportType}`);
 73 |     throw new Error("Invalid transport type specified");
 74 |   }
 75 | };
 76 | 
 77 | app.get("/sse", async (req, res) => {
 78 |   try {
 79 |     console.log("New SSE connection");
 80 | 
 81 |     const backingServerTransport = await createTransport(req.query);
 82 | 
 83 |     console.log("Connected MCP client to backing server transport");
 84 | 
 85 |     const webAppTransport = new SSEServerTransport("/message", res);
 86 |     console.log("Created web app transport");
 87 | 
 88 |     webAppTransports.push(webAppTransport);
 89 |     console.log("Created web app transport");
 90 | 
 91 |     await webAppTransport.start();
 92 | 
 93 |     if (backingServerTransport instanceof StdioClientTransport) {
 94 |       backingServerTransport.stderr!.on("data", (chunk) => {
 95 |         webAppTransport.send({
 96 |           jsonrpc: "2.0",
 97 |           method: "notifications/stderr",
 98 |           params: {
 99 |             content: chunk.toString(),
100 |           },
101 |         });
102 |       });
103 |     }
104 | 
105 |     mcpProxy({
106 |       transportToClient: webAppTransport,
107 |       transportToServer: backingServerTransport,
108 |       onerror: (error) => {
109 |         console.error(error);
110 |       },
111 |     });
112 | 
113 |     console.log("Set up MCP proxy");
114 |   } catch (error) {
115 |     console.error("Error in /sse route:", error);
116 |     res.status(500).json(error);
117 |   }
118 | });
119 | 
120 | app.post("/message", async (req, res) => {
121 |   try {
122 |     const sessionId = req.query.sessionId;
123 |     console.log(`Received message for sessionId ${sessionId}`);
124 | 
125 |     const transport = webAppTransports.find((t) => t.sessionId === sessionId);
126 |     if (!transport) {
127 |       res.status(404).end("Session not found");
128 |       return;
129 |     }
130 |     await transport.handlePostMessage(req, res);
131 |   } catch (error) {
132 |     console.error("Error in /message route:", error);
133 |     res.status(500).json(error);
134 |   }
135 | });
136 | 
137 | app.get("/config", (req, res) => {
138 |   try {
139 |     const defaultEnvironment = getDefaultEnvironment();
140 | 
141 |     res.json({
142 |       defaultEnvironment,
143 |       defaultCommand: values.env,
144 |       defaultArgs: values.args,
145 |     });
146 |   } catch (error) {
147 |     console.error("Error in /config route:", error);
148 |     res.status(500).json(error);
149 |   }
150 | });
151 | 
152 | const PORT = process.env.PORT || 3000;
153 | app.listen(PORT, () => {});
154 |

/server/src/mcpProxy.ts:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 1 | import { Transport } from "@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/shared/transport.js";
 2 | 
 3 | export default function mcpProxy({
 4 |   transportToClient,
 5 |   transportToServer,
 6 |   onerror,
 7 | }: {
 8 |   transportToClient: Transport;
 9 |   transportToServer: Transport;
10 |   onerror: (error: Error) => void;
11 | }) {
12 |   let transportToClientClosed = false;
13 |   let transportToServerClosed = false;
14 | 
15 |   transportToClient.onmessage = (message) => {
16 |     transportToServer.send(message).catch(onerror);
17 |   };
18 | 
19 |   transportToServer.onmessage = (message) => {
20 |     transportToClient.send(message).catch(onerror);
21 |   };
22 | 
23 |   transportToClient.onclose = () => {
24 |     if (transportToServerClosed) {
25 |       return;
26 |     }
27 | 
28 |     transportToClientClosed = true;
29 |     transportToServer.close().catch(onerror);
30 |   };
31 | 
32 |   transportToServer.onclose = () => {
33 |     if (transportToClientClosed) {
34 |       return;
35 |     }
36 |     transportToServerClosed = true;
37 | 
38 |     transportToClient.close().catch(onerror);
39 |   };
40 | 
41 |   transportToClient.onerror = onerror;
42 |   transportToServer.onerror = onerror;
43 | }
44 |

/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1 | # Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
  2 | 
  3 | ## Our Pledge
  4 | 
  5 | We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in our
  6 | community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body
  7 | size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender
  8 | identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status,
  9 | nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity
 10 | and orientation.
 11 | 
 12 | We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming,
 13 | diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.
 14 | 
 15 | ## Our Standards
 16 | 
 17 | Examples of behavior that contributes to a positive environment for our
 18 | community include:
 19 | 
 20 | * Demonstrating empathy and kindness toward other people
 21 | * Being respectful of differing opinions, viewpoints, and experiences
 22 | * Giving and gracefully accepting constructive feedback
 23 | * Accepting responsibility and apologizing to those affected by our mistakes,
 24 |   and learning from the experience
 25 | * Focusing on what is best not just for us as individuals, but for the
 26 |   overall community
 27 | 
 28 | Examples of unacceptable behavior include:
 29 | 
 30 | * The use of sexualized language or imagery, and sexual attention or
 31 |   advances of any kind
 32 | * Trolling, insulting or derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
 33 | * Public or private harassment
 34 | * Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or email
 35 |   address, without their explicit permission
 36 | * Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a
 37 |   professional setting
 38 | 
 39 | ## Enforcement Responsibilities
 40 | 
 41 | Community leaders are responsible for clarifying and enforcing our standards of
 42 | acceptable behavior and will take appropriate and fair corrective action in
 43 | response to any behavior that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive,
 44 | or harmful.
 45 | 
 46 | Community leaders have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject
 47 | comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are
 48 | not aligned to this Code of Conduct, and will communicate reasons for moderation
 49 | decisions when appropriate.
 50 | 
 51 | ## Scope
 52 | 
 53 | This Code of Conduct applies within all community spaces, and also applies when
 54 | an individual is officially representing the community in public spaces.
 55 | Examples of representing our community include using an official e-mail address,
 56 | posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed
 57 | representative at an online or offline event.
 58 | 
 59 | ## Enforcement
 60 | 
 61 | Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be
 62 | reported to the community leaders responsible for enforcement at
 63 | mcp-coc@anthropic.com.
 64 | All complaints will be reviewed and investigated promptly and fairly.
 65 | 
 66 | All community leaders are obligated to respect the privacy and security of the
 67 | reporter of any incident.
 68 | 
 69 | ## Enforcement Guidelines
 70 | 
 71 | Community leaders will follow these Community Impact Guidelines in determining
 72 | the consequences for any action they deem in violation of this Code of Conduct:
 73 | 
 74 | ### 1. Correction
 75 | 
 76 | **Community Impact**: Use of inappropriate language or other behavior deemed
 77 | unprofessional or unwelcome in the community.
 78 | 
 79 | **Consequence**: A private, written warning from community leaders, providing
 80 | clarity around the nature of the violation and an explanation of why the
 81 | behavior was inappropriate. A public apology may be requested.
 82 | 
 83 | ### 2. Warning
 84 | 
 85 | **Community Impact**: A violation through a single incident or series
 86 | of actions.
 87 | 
 88 | **Consequence**: A warning with consequences for continued behavior. No
 89 | interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with
 90 | those enforcing the Code of Conduct, for a specified period of time. This
 91 | includes avoiding interactions in community spaces as well as external channels
 92 | like social media. Violating these terms may lead to a temporary or
 93 | permanent ban.
 94 | 
 95 | ### 3. Temporary Ban
 96 | 
 97 | **Community Impact**: A serious violation of community standards, including
 98 | sustained inappropriate behavior.
 99 | 
100 | **Consequence**: A temporary ban from any sort of interaction or public
101 | communication with the community for a specified period of time. No public or
102 | private interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction
103 | with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, is allowed during this period.
104 | Violating these terms may lead to a permanent ban.
105 | 
106 | ### 4. Permanent Ban
107 | 
108 | **Community Impact**: Demonstrating a pattern of violation of community
109 | standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior,  harassment of an
110 | individual, or aggression toward or disparagement of classes of individuals.
111 | 
112 | **Consequence**: A permanent ban from any sort of public interaction within
113 | the community.
114 | 
115 | ## Attribution
116 | 
117 | This Code of Conduct is adapted from the [Contributor Covenant][homepage],
118 | version 2.0, available at
119 | https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html.
120 | 
121 | Community Impact Guidelines were inspired by [Mozilla's code of conduct
122 | enforcement ladder](https://github.com/mozilla/diversity).
123 | 
124 | [homepage]: https://www.contributor-covenant.org
125 | 
126 | For answers to common questions about this code of conduct, see the FAQ at
127 | https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations are available at
128 | https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.
129 |
